column15: Faculty Issue - Not enough Faculty members

column11: We lack some faculty expertise
I suspect that having faculty integrate some bioinformatics assignments in their courses is more work that most faculty want to do.
resources - computers!!softwaretrained faculty

There are no good ways to re-tool for those of us who are interested. All workshops at Cold Spring Harbor are in the middle of the semester and the Yale course in June (computational immunology, which is best suited for my field) is impossible to get intoif you are not a student/postdoc at a research institution. I'll keep looking and applying, but I am starting to feel excluded from the process
General comfort with computational tools and statistics are always limiting...
Too few faculty members; not enough time to fit in bioinformatics courses.

Lack of faculty experience with field (only dedicated faculty is from Comp. Sci. and focuses on big data broadly, not necessarily specific biological/biochemical questions and combining bioinformatics with hypothesis-driven wet bench work).
Curriculum needs overhaul
Others in the department do not think this is important.  None of us have much training in bioinformatics.
None.
Content requirements for life science students.

Concepts of bioinformatics should be included in core courses to help students build competency. Upper level courses should also teach some bioinformatics most appropriate to the subject matter. (It should be integrated,not necessarily separate).
Separation of departments; not enough seats in the bioinformatics courses currently offered to handle all of our majors.
need faculty and instructors with sufficient expertise
faculty expertise to teach!
Resource issues - number of department faculty is at a historical low, but this will probably change over the next few years
The bioinformatics courses are very much geared towards writing code

We can't find qualified faculty. Qualified faculty are those who have a computer scientist level understanding of computers and a biologist level understanding of biology, and focus on computers for the sake of answering biological questions. We find manywho have one of the three requirements, but not all three.
biology departments don't have the resources to add faculty and classes to their departments.  Same with the stats and CS departments.
Old professors don't want to learn/teach new things.
Faculty and grad students needed for entry level to informatics for all students
I think we need to introduce bioinformatics approaches at every level of instruction. There are excellent applications in cell/molecular-based courses as well as ecol/evolution-based courses.
too few faculty for too many students
we have  some courses but not enough students take them. We are limited by class size constraints
Faculty buy-in for curriculum revision of biology major related courses.
Not a requirement for most Bio majors.
Platform hosting, standardized interface.
Introductory programming classes
Need prerequisite programming courses aimed at LS undergraduates
Limited computers on which students can access software
funding, faculty time
Lack of sufficient educators
Curriculum is already overloaded in biology degree programs and courses.
Some students have problems using databases and analyzing data.

As mentioned above, time constraints due to other content/skills that needs to be covered.  Time constraints on developing new materials (there is never enough time to develop new activities given all of the contact and prep and grading hours faculty geneally put in.)  Also, professional development to help faculty who are no longer research active to keep up with current and new tools.
Traditional teaching is a major barrier.
A lot of unfamiliarity with the techniques and, therefore, hesitance to teach the subject. I only teach bioinformatics as part of the SEA PHAGES in silico curriculum.
Time
Infrastructure for data analysis and management.
We need more faculty that are able to teach these courses.
The lack of computer facilities and software for the students to use is one of our limitions.
There is little room left in the curriculum for additional courses. Others would need to be phased out.
Faculty time to develop courses.   Courses may not be seen as essential for "pre-med" intent students.
People qualified and interested in doing so
Lack of faculty with content knowledge to teach these courses
Limited resources for incorporating bioinformatics into classroom setting
faculty cannot teach bioinformatics or are scared to incorporate
The biggest barrier is time for students to take extra courses.
Not sufficient numbers of faculty to teach new courses.
A course dedicated specifically to genomics and genome analysis
Lack of knowledge on the part of the faculty, inertia from using old curricula

The main current barrier is time. Those faculty who would like to teach these courses have not yet been tenured, and so are discouraged from taking the time to develop an entirely new course. This should change soon.
getting new faculty lines approved
Institutional inertia is a problem. New disciplines are difficult to establish and bioinformatics is one of them.
Deciding how to include bioinformatics without making the course a bioinformatics course.
We need more content expertise and continuing education in this subject.
We just hired a new Bioinformatics prof.
Few to no faculty with bioinformatics expertise.
faculty with expertise to teach these courses
varying os platforms, discomfort with unix command line, general unfamiliarity with computing
-faculty expertise and confidence to teach such coursework.

The various biology majors at my institution have few elective units for students to fulfill with bioinformatics courses.  So until existing major requirements are reduced we risk starving the existing courses for bioinformatics by adding new ones.
Lack of qualified instructors
Workload, lack of expertise, time for developing courses or modules for integration into courses
Financial
Time
We need to have our students doing statistics and bioinformatics much earlier
Faculty with the expertise, mainly. And the difficulty of re-vamping existing curriculum.
Time is the big barrier... community college faculty are ridiculously busy, and professional development funding and/or course release opportunities are very limited, at least within this system.
Hard to find the right faculty to staff these courses.

The faculty at my university are not trained in bioinformatics, and they seem a little wary of integrating a subject they know little about into all of their courses (mostly because they are unsure of feasibility, and not fully convinced of the centralityof bioinformatics to biology courses)
faculty spread too thin already.
We do not have enough faculty expertise to offer these courses.
learning curve of coding and scripting, institutional roadblocks on courses shared between departments
Lack of dedicated computer labs.  There is only one such lab at my institution and I have to limit my use of this classroom to evening classes.
Money, Time.  I am promoted based on publications, not teaching.  So time for class development cannot be top priority.
other courses include genetics, developmental biology, molecular biology
For the moment, not all students in life science have bioinformatics courses. They all should have some.
We need professional develoment help for many of our faculty in this area

Depends on exactly what is meant by "bioinformatics". If it is truly the computer science based aspects of the field, then most biologists including myself don't have the computer science skills to program. If it just using existing programs, then that isless of a barrier.
Professors need more training, students do not like Math, need for more criticla thinking skills
time and room in the curriculum
Computing facilities, student preparation

Our faculty is already stretched thin teaching the core courses in our major, courses for non-biology majors, and the few specialty courses we are able to teach. With faculty positions being limited, it is difficult for us to find the time in our already ull teaching loads to teach bioinformatics.

Lack of institutional support for program with few majorsLack of interdisciplinary initiatives - stovepipe mentality, competition for resources, majorsFailure to support grant-funded programsFailure to support infrastructure: servers purchased w/ grnt funds no longer maintained by system-admin - responsibility falls on programFailure to support mechanisms to identify viable options for cloud-based computing resources to support major and research projectsUnrealistic expectations for research, pulications, grant activities given current teaching load
adequate computers; adequate availability of computer labs for courses

I am working with a biology colleague to develop an advanced evolutionary biology class that would include quite a bit of bioinformatics, but we have been slow to finalize the course and get university approval - hopefully up and running in a year or so.
Just the lack of faculty interested
Not enough qualified instructors to teach courses in bioinformatics
Main barrier I see is lack of basic of command line computing skills.  If students were more familiar with bash commands and scripts teaching bioinformatics concepts were be more productive.

Genomics/Bioinformatics/Computational Biology is a new major initiative at Colby, expected to grow in the coming year or so.  We currently have a new Computational Biology major and are preparing to graduate our first handful of majors in May.  Barriers: retraining of existing faculty; new course development; hiring of new faculty/staff in computer science, biology, and stats; computational infrastructure resources/staff; space limitations in science facilities; developing student interest in this directin
Most of the faculty in life science departments at my institution are ill-prepared (as am I) to educate others on this subject.

One of the lab components (in freshman biology class) is to generate molecular portfolio for the assigned protein. In this students are asked to download sequence in faster format for the assigned accession number. Identify conserved domain. Find the infomation about corresponding gene, and associated features. etc....
we have recently hired someone who will bring additional expertise in this area into our department, and I think this will reduce barriers greatly

need to design good, interesting exercises (time-consuming!) and availability of knowledgeable grad student  for demonstrators, availability of suitable room with many workstations AND a clear view to a projector screen for the class. Plus need to get thelarge classes into smaller groups
old faculty
funding, more faculty
we are interested in potentially hiring in that area
Please see above comments
Poor math/statistical skills and low level of technical background of our students.
Faculty expertise in bioinformatics presents challenges for broad implementation of bioinformatics content.
Time.  Our students have a set curriculum that prevents additional such course offerings.
I think bioinformatics content should be more infused in core bio courses
We need a course devoted to bioinformatics, and especially genomic-level approaches.  Barriers include staffing and expertise.
I haven't had time to develop a bioinformatics course since developing my own skills during a recent sabbatical leave. I expect to offer a course for the first time in 2017-2018.
Time, staffing and number of credits required for other things.
Time and money.
Staffing sufficient to teach both courses required for the major and teach classes that are "wanted."
Lack of faculty support, from what I have seen; too many "more important" concepts to cover in a non-majors or majors biology lab or lecture.
students who do not have strong background in molecular biology and genetics find difficulties in a) interpreting results generated by bioinformatic tools, b) appreciating the power of bioinformatics
Time to develop courses.
Having a faculty member who feels comfortable teaching the content.
Biology faculty

Articulation agreements with 4-year transfer institutions. California has the C-ID system, where specific courses have specific course IDs (C-IDs), and these form sequences that students take for transfer. This is dictated by SB 1440, so it is CA law. We ust transfer our students with 60 units into degrees at the CSU to be completed in 120 units. No room for courses without C-IDs, and no stand alone courses are approved by our Senate, and by our Chancellor's office. This is a problem for implementing morebioinformatics into a course, as the curriculum outline is dictated by C-ID; and an additional course would not be approved.
Lack of resources.
Deciding as a department on outcomes and which courses will take time and leadership in order to bring forth changes.
lack of knowledge within the faculty of the biology department

Student interest and enrollment is a barrier, since the classes are electives and most of our students are pre-clinical. Student preparation is also a barrier since students have little math, statistics, or computer science background to apply to bioinforatics courses.
We have recently redone our five core courses that all biology students take. Within this framework we have added bioinformatics components to those courses.
Faculty with expertise and interest (e.g. use it in their research) whose courses wouldbe accessible to all science majors
Current credits in our department, dedicated computer-laboratory space, $$, concept of reducing credits to degree
Knowledge on the part of the professors, and low number of faculty to teach required courses
Money
see above
lack of support from colleagues. colleagues lack of understanding the importance of bioinformatics

It takes time to educate ourselves about bioinformatics beyond any limited amount we may use in our small research programs, but with all the other duties and responsibilities we have to put our time into, from planning, teaching, and assessing our course, to advising, to diversity issues, to student recruitment and student retention activities, to communication with the omnipresent email/texts, oh, and somewhere in there we are supposed to do some research.  Basically, there are more priorities than ther is time. It is difficult to make time to educate ourselves in any substantial way.
Knowledge and expertise

It seems to me that the amount of work to even propose changes to our course offerings would be substantial, and would require proof that a demand for such a course exists, all of which I am not interested in taking on myself.
Insufficient mathematics preparation, insufficient programming skills, lack of emphasis on the importance of these skills
Workload issues.  Not enough faculty.
Large class sizes.
Faculty not having sufficient time to learn new methods and incorporate into classroom.
I believe we are developing one
Fitting into already content crowded courses, faculty understanding of bionformatics

Currently, we are a branch campus of a major state university that only offer the first two years of the biology program.  These students then transfer to the main campus after sophomore year.  However, we are currently growing in numbers and have the potntial to begin offering all 4-years.  Once approved, we will incorporate bioinformatics into the curriculum.
Too few faculty to add additional courses.

We currently offer one course.  Either there needs to be a means of training all the faculty on integrating bioinformatics in the courses they currently teach (my preference) or we need to develop more courses rooted in bioinformatics.
I offered to develop such a course collaborating with a CSci/Math prof who does bioinformatics research, but we were not able to get releases from our current courses to offer the new course.
Lack of knowledge among the faculty.
heavy teaching loads
expertise in the faculty
Additional course would be offered as an elective and may face low enrollment barrier to run regularly. Also, prerequisite courses may hinder enrollment of a more diverse group of students.
The field is relatively new and we need to learn how to integrate it into our program.
We don't have the faculty within our department to teach a dedicated course. Students may not have the computational background to take such a course.
expertise and faculty workload; reliant on many adjuncts with current class offerings; hard to imagine finding time to develop let alone teach such a course
Faculty with expertise, and faculty with time in their teaching load (past requirements) to teach them.
Time to develop; lack of expertise on most up to date bioinformatics tools, and knowledge to tailor an activity to undergraduate level.
Faculty's mindset and administration's inertia
Time and resources (teaching tools, modules, etc.) to get more faculty to implement into their courses.
Faculty development.
A server dedicated to the Biology department with greater access for students
The college's security settings for students (way too high) for running open source software
I think that some of the faculty are not comfortable teaching bioinformatics tools and techniques.
Not many of our professors have the ability to teach this content.
time, conversation about integrated curricula
Our faculty are expected to maintain funded research programs so teaching and developing new programs are not top priority.
Currently the biggest barrier is faculty knowledge.  Only two of use use bioinformatics in our research.  Many of the others are willing but lack training.

We need more quantitative skills integration, not just bioinformatics.  Interpreting data is central to biology but is not taught in every class even though we have tried to make that happen.  There are many barriers familiar to readers of Vision and Chane that prevent curricular updating.
Expertise, time, and lab equipment (e.g., microarray instrumentation)

Some faculty members are not familiar or comfortable with bioinformatics content. At my institution, we all teach a heavy load and collaborating on curriculum development tends to take a couple years before content is ready.
We have just hired a new faculty member with this expertise to increase the amount of bioinformatics in our curriculum
Administration not wanting anything to change.
We are in the process of starting a Biotechnology program at the college, and will be integrating a great deal of bioinformatics in our biotechnology courses.
The computer infrastructure is really weak.
For courses with many instructors, adding a bioinformatics unit might be difficult due to lack of expertise.
Faculty with the proper training, number of hours that students need to take to graduate

I think it just hasn't been suggested.  There are certain meat-and-potatoes courses in the department, and they need the idea to be brought to the department and cultivated.  I'm new to the college - I think that person could be me!
Alignment of course learning objectives to include bioinformatics

Our biology majors already have substantial requirements for graduation, it is difficult to fit new courses into the curriculum. Also many instructors do not have sufficient background in bioinformatics.
Faculty knowledge
funding

There is some resistance from experimental biologists to include algorithmic aspects of bioinformatics. As a consequence, most bioinformatics modules end up focusing on various tools alone. I strongly feel that students should have at least a rudimentary nderstanding of the algorithms driving bioinformatics tools. There lies another challenge: not many experimental biologists have a good understanding of the algorithms.
Time/space, must fit in with 4-year guaranteed transfer to have enough student enrollment
few faculty with natural history bioinformatics expertise;  most faculty in my department equate bioinformatics with molecular data, not natural history collections data!
small institution/small department, therefore limited opportunities
The main issue is not having specialized and dedicated faculty with the proper mathematical and computational training.
More information is needed on the topic.
Faculty that lack the knowledge. Most of our faculty are older and have no experience in bioinformatics.
I have found some students don't have computers are either trying to use computers at the library or complete their courses using mobile devices like phones or Chromebooks.
Relatively few barriers, but in some cases software licensing fees and student interest are concerns
Need faculty with bioinformatics background who have time to teach a course of this type.  Large numbers of majors make offering new course challenging at my institution.
Supporting linear algebra and programming courses should be offered as prerequisites
Faculty lack specific training in bioinformatics and don't have the resources (personnel or funds) to spend on software and equipment.
Lack of faculty expertise in bioinformatics; lack of teaching capacity for an additional course in the curriculum.
not likely to be popular for students to take
access to computer labs
We run in trimester sessions which are very intensive, also we don't have many faculty with bioinformatics expertise.
120 hour course limit for degree.  This is my first year at this university.  Taught 8 years elsewhere.
Computer labs large enough to teach lab sections
Bioinformatics is interdisciplinary and requires buy-in from biology, chemistry, mathematics, and computer science. But each of these programs are busy with their own priorities.
The diversity if topics relevant to life scientists is ever growing and more advanced courses would be essential.
We do not have a strong statistics or computer science component on campus at the moment, so this is a major barrier.
Regular access to the internet is a huge obstacle. I teach in a rural environment and internet access is not required of our students due the issues with high speed access
We don't have anyone with bioinformatics experience at our institution.
We are developing a Biotechnology major, and there will be a bioinformatics course for that, which will also be available to our biology majors.

Many of my colleagues are not aware of the importance of bioinformatics in biological research.  My institution lacks a computer science department, so I must seek bioinformatics expertise and collaborators outside my institution.
insufficient student interest, insufficient instructor expertise and time
small university, limited as to how many electives we can offer per semester in terms of having enough students per class to let them run
We're a 2 year school and have a lot of content to cover in just a few semesters; transfer of courses is an issue too
Time.  We have core competencies that must be addressed.  Many students are less competent in basic computing skills than I assumed when I included bioinformatic labs in my courses.
Without expertise available we need readily applicable lab activities designed for implementation; app for mol gen is obvious, but how applied for nutrition, A&P, envs would be helpful.
availability of faculty with experience in bioinformatics

I strongly think that there bioinformatics should be integrated through the biology (life sciences) curriculum, but I think there should also be stand-alone courses in computer science and bioinformatics for those students who might consider a career in boinformatics.
We are too busy teaching other courses and its hard to add a new one.  Also, our faculty aren't formally trained in bioinformatics.
There are no faculty competent or passionate enough about this field to teach appropriately.
Teaching load.  Cost of wet lab (though getting much less expensive).  Lack of student interest (will not help them get into dental school, medical school, PA school, etc.).
limited resources (i.e., available faculty)
Large classes, little recognition for development of or teaching new courses.

Workload is a major issue at my institution. Faculty are required to teach 34 credits per year on a 12-month schedule (and most are expected to teach adjunct as well), leaving little time for course development. There is no allowance or support for innovaion or course improvement.
Server access, IT support.
Time and availability to teach. Also, expertise of other faculty in such areas.
in process of developing resources
Faculty inertia; need to teach course descriptions and common course objectives that do not necessarily include bioinformatics

I have thought about this a lot.  I am planning on just doing a short "paper version" of bioinformatics concepts with my microbiology students (sophomores).  The current software has too high of a learning curve for an activity that will only cover one la.
Insufficient numbers of faculty, insufficient time in students' degrees.

Lack of faculty professional development in genomics/bioinformatics content and use of associated technologies (especially computational skills); lack of faculty recognition about the importance of genomics/bioinformatics across biology curriculum
I suppose it's mainly lack of funding for higher institutions.
Lack of faculty with the background to teach such courses and a lack of space in the curriculum
second follow on course--time is the chief issues
It is in the works!
faculty expertise
At our school, there is very limited funding and support to create new upper-level biology courses that would take instructors out of our high-seating-capacity (high-profit) classes.
The courses would likely be low-enrollment and we are always under a budget crunch.  There is nearly zero chance that such a course would become required in the near future.
same comments as above
Cost and student interest.  Most of our students need developmental math courses to bring them to a basic college algebra level.
Full schedule of activities; multiple classes; multiple campuses
Faculty knowledge and experience
Same as above
development of certificate curriculumneed discussions with knowledgable bioinformatics educators
Lack of professors with training in this area
insufficient faculty to offer a general bioinformatics course
time. coordination of other faculty in multi-section courses with shared curriculum

faculty to teach the course(s).  i am essentially a single-person discipline, primarily teaching cell biology and genetics courses.  i have recently added a bioinformatics course, but am pretty much stretched to my curricular limit!
It is hard to include bioinformatics when we are always pressed for time on the content we do have. The question always is: What do I remove to fit this into the curriculum?
Lots of required courses, not enough students to split among electives

One barrier is having qualified faculty. Another is making room in the existing curriculum. And third having the support to explore adding more bioinformatics topics and/or courses into the curriculum.
My department does not do curriculum reform with regularity.
existing student course load, lack of faculty
Hands on projects in bioinformatics are technically challenging for our student population.

Among biology faculty, lack of discussions about updating and evaluating the curriculum in order to integrate genomics and bioinformatics in to courses. Lack of knowledge of bioinformatics.  Lack of discussions with computer scientists at the college.
It is a very small school, difficult to get enough student interest

There are bioinformatics courses but mostly just a small number of comp. sci. and BINF majors take the courses. The majority of STEM majors are BIOL majors and they do not take BINF courses and bioinformatics is not incorporated into our majors Biology corses.

We currently don't have anyone who feels qualified to build an entire course around the topic, and, frankly, modifying an existing course requires time that we currently don't have to donate. There is definitely an "activation energy" barrier.
See above.
I am the only one with bioinformatics experience who is willing to teach it
Time to develop problems, appropriate textbooks, fitting it in the curriculum
we have a hiring freeze for > 5 years and have not been able to hire someone in this field
Time and talent: we are a small university that has not been able to allow for the creation of a bioinformatics course.

Scheduling and time constraints - we only have enough room in the schedule for a certain number of electives. Bioinformatics used to be in the rotation but we do not currently have anyone with the load to teach it.
Understanding genetics, zoology and botany can be challenging without a background in bioinformatics.
Lack of information.
Few faculty members with bioinformatics expertise.
Time constraints
Qualified faculty
we lack any content on -omics analysis as none of the faculty are trained in this.
Lack of knowledge on the subject.
see above - still a debate about whether data analysis should be taught in excel or R
I would like to add more myself. Time for curriculum development is hard. Would love to plug and play with curriculum.

Time to develop course modules/content. We frequently don't know our teaching assignments until 2-3 months (and rarely 2 weeks) before the semester begins. If we had more time, then collaboration and coordination could happen.
Lack of adcuate computer labs form implementation.  Need to time to set curriculum.  Create a course will take a very long time in my campus.
change is happening slowly
time to fit into curriculum, availability of computers, faculty/graduate students with expertise are limited

At our institution, bioinformatics is the province of a very anti-social colleague who will not help any of us bring it to the classroom.  He teaches one senior level seminar to no more than 15 elite hand-picked students each academic year who (in my opinon) get a warped, narrow view of the subject.
Training and technology.

I'm not sure how I or others or you are defining bioinformatics. Certainly understanding the resources that are in use is a big factor, and the need to cover basic classic ideas in some detail precludes inclusion of more recent innovations in many courses

Lack of appreciation for bioinformatics by older faculty members (e.g., blatantly passing over the chapters in the intro textbook that integrate genomics/bioinformatics into the genetics part of the intro curriculum because they are too "niche"); lack of olleagues who use bioinformatic in research; lack of money to hire new faculty in this new type of area.
Student interest
(1) resources (faculty time/load) and (2) perceived need (or lack thereof)
Lack of faculty with expertise.
We are relatively a new school and developing programs.
Time/Faculty
software?
Admin need to be aware that Bioinformatics training is vital in today's Biotech/Pharma workforce.
lack of knowledge
faculty time, resources
instructors with the skills to teach bioinformatics
Time and small number of students
Resistance in the department to changing curricula and using technology; many professors do not see it as necessary, important or something the students could handle
Lack of qualified instructors (I have some experience but no FORMAL training) and lack of interest of administrative leaders.
lack of inclusion by faculty, trained prior to its explosion
I think the barriers are mostly time and expertise
No real barriers. Just that I have not used bioinformatics tools since 2007 and need to get updated.

I teach a Genomics course where we use bioinformatics tools to analyze data and perform original research through the Genomics Education Partnership.  However, we don't have a course where students develop bioinformatics tools themselves, so we need a tru bioinformatics course in addition to the Genomics course.
Course design is time consuming and any assistance with course modules would be beneficial

There are several upper division elective courses that include bioinformatics activities or modules.  We need to consider offering a course, or at least a group of modules, on a required basis.  We are discouraged from collaborating/team teaching because f workload assignment confusion.  Many of our students are ill-prepared in reagrds to mathematical skills.
Faculty interest and expertise.
We are in the process of implementing more bioinformatics content.
students don't have enough math / critical thinking skills. I do'nt know that much about bioinformatics.
My school is a cheapskate and won't hire new faculty to cover aspects of bioinformatics.
They need to be incorporated into general Life Sciences course more regularly.
Infrastructure. Small university, no space to dedicate "computer lab" any more. Using combination of mobile computer lab and personal computers; problems with connectivity/support
Not enough time for a proper lab so we use homework to solve real problems.
Not enough faculty to teach the current course offerings.
We have just approved a course on Biostatistics that may include bioinformatics.  When I think of bioinformatics I think of huge data bases...largely from genetics and molecular biology
time and opposition to the idea of bioinformatics as an important skill for undergrads
Faculty member who taught courses left

Computer access.  Most of my students have their own laptop computers, but many are in a tough financial situation such that they cannot afford a replacement if anything goes wrong with their current computer.  Our on-campus access to computers [and especally printers] is very limited.  My wish list includes a short-term or quarter-long laptop loan program.
Faculty expertise, equipment
It is not seen as a priority by the administration.

Wet labs are showy and computational work is not as showy when it is happening, so I think there may be a tendency to minimize bioinformatics for this reason.   One colleague says it is not hypothesis driven and that it is essentially just DNA barcoding
currently teaching loads don't allow us to offer very many elective courses

Very few teaching faculty (including myself) are well-versed in bioinformatics. Once we pass a training, it is hard to figure out issues by yourself without a regular support when things are not working out. Students usually find it hard and push back.
our courseload is too heavy alreaady
Faculty feel lack of familiarity
Often, financial support for community colleges
Time required for course development. Lack of technical support
We don't have the expertise in our faculty.
We will probably need funding to purchase software licenses.
work load is already too great
Our computer facilities are aging and poorly maintained.  The students are disinclined to move beyond their phones to work on projects.

There is not much interest.  I think it is an essential part of science education and would like to develop a topics course in bioinformatics i microbiology in addition to incorporating exercises into existing courses in microbiology.
Not valued enough by faculty (yet) to make it a required part of undergraduate education.
Computer labs that are easily accessible.
Faculty unwilling to learn information to add bioinformatics curriculum in their courses.
knowledgable faculty

Students majoring in the life sciences often fear bioinformatics or don't see its relevance. They often get frustrated when tools don't work, and overall shortcomings in technology literacy is a barrier for most students.

The biggest barrier is deciding what other 'critical' information to drop from the undergraduate curriculum. Biology is expanding as a field and so, offering a 'Biology' B.S. means that decisions about what to include in the curriculum must be balanced wih decisions of what to cut. We already have a larger mandated number of courses than most other majors, adding more would be a challenge. It's also difficult for established faculty, like myself, to stay up to date in the fast changing field of bioinformaics. When I developed my bioinformatics labs, 20 years ago, they were cutting edge. While still useful to our students today, I have not been able to receive training that would allow me to make reasoned decisions about how to update the curriculum.
Not a lot of faculty expertise in the area.
Lack of communication between the Computer Science and Biology Departments prevents development of an advanced course in bioinformatics
Pre-med requirements drive enrollments too much.
The biology curriculum is overloaded.  Every faculty members believes his or her specialty is necessary for all students so there isn't room for my specialty.
We have a new Biotechnology course that may include some bioinformatics in the future, but right now the instructor is just working out the initial content
Primary barrier is lack of knowledge of the faculty - we ourselves are trying to come up to speed with modern bioinformatic approaches and are not yet proficient enough to teach others.
not enough faculty members qualified to teach this content
teaching load already high, we have a lot of expertise though
Misunderstanding of bioinformatics; concern that the math/stats are too difficult for undergraduates; fear of change / new things

Lack of student buy-in, lack of support for computational needs (no computer science department, limited CS classes), no 'free time' to teach additional courses (all the faculty in the department are already on overload)
Instructors have too much of a requirement to teach "in the core"
Huge barrier to getting computer science on board with this.  Partly as a result of this, life science majors do not, in general, learn to code at all.

Honestly, staffing and time are the largest barriers.  I teach at a small undergraduate college, and we provide a solid but basic foundation in biology.  We all struggle to incorporate more specialized classes and/or topics.
The state university system is currently culling biology courses from our Biology Degree program, requiring fewer courses in the maths and sciences.
In a large lecture setting it is very difficult to get them to do anything that is hands on.
lack of faculty expertise and time to develop expertise

Students are generally not aware of what the subject material and therefore do not see its importance to their future careers.  I have a number of other courses in my rotation- adding another is not feasible.  I don't get any support from math and compute science department- they seem uninterested in bioinformatics.
Already full curriculum for students.Faculty caught up in older topics
People are not very familiar with it, and people do not have time to re-design labs/lecture content
Poor background among faculty.
faculty expertise

I don't have the expertise in programming to put together a true bioinformatics course.  I do bioinformatics light in my molecular biology course.  I am interested in creating a medical and bioinformatics course.  This would include both database work andcoding.  Ideally this course would be at the sophomore level.
Small faculty size makes it difficult to incorporate new materialQuantitative literacy of our students could be better
No time/personnel available to teach.

microbiology should include bioinformatics but institutional lethargy to incorporate new paradigms in learning exist.  Health care decisions makers at the community college level are not seeing the applications in genetic counseling.
Life sciences students typically don't take intro programming courses
Student course load and lack of flexibility in terms of taking biology electives because of the heavy course load outside of that.
Credit limitations for degree.  Institution will not allow courses that are not required for the major to be taught.  Lack of computing infrastructure.

We are on the (10-week) quarter system so there is little flexibility to add to existing courses.  We barely have enough faculty to cover our existing curriculum so we'd have to cut out some classes to make room and there would be general resistance to tht.

My institution has hired a number of computer scientists due to an influx of students majoring in computer science especially for a MS degree. One of those computer scientists is a bioinformatics specialist. She also has a bachelor's degree in biomedical ngineering. My hope is that we can collaborate to build a few courses that integrate life science (molecular biology and genetics, my specialties) and bioinformatics. We have had a few conversations about this, but have not yet made concrete plans. A potetial barrier to making the collaboration happen is from my colleagues in biology. They fear that building life science expertise will diminish the traditional zoology/botany training we offer.
Instructor knowledge, student readiness, time to integrate activities into the current curriculum
Lack of well thought out biological sciences curriculum has led to courses being offered that faculty want to teach as opposed to what is best for students.
Mostly the need to cover existing courses in classical areas.
Not yet developed

Students have fear or math and programming that killed my department's first attempt at this.  No one wanted to take the classes.  I think that integrating bioinformatics concepts in traditional biology curricula first would make offering a course like ths more appealing.
The biggest barrier would be the technology offered in the building that the sciences are taught.
Not enough students to offer such an elective. Not enough time in introductory courses.

Again, the barrier to inclusion of bioinformatics rests with the administration of this College and particularly with those who decide what Courses to off the students and the instructional Texts adopted.
Lack of faculty time and expertise
I'd like to see us offer a bioinformatics course that uses some common software tools that companies like to see our students knowing about, like NGS analysis, particularly RNA-Seq.
The college I work for is in transition from the 2 year to 4 year vision.
Need IT support.
Same comment as above. Institutional leadership and many faculty lack training and background in quantitative biology.
We are currently submitting to the curriculum committee an undergraduate research course that will certainly include significant use of bioinformatics.

Not enough students are registering for bioinformatics classes.
limited faculty with background/experience
Lack of facilities and full-time faculty with the knowledge and skills to teach the courses. Most faculty here are part-time and have very little input in curriculum.
If simplified versions of lesson plans or labs were available it could be a great application teaching tool for all levels of students.
A freshman or sophomore course in programing would help students get acquainted with the CS skills, but it is difficult to fit into schedules that are packed with other science and math courses.

Many of my "bench science" colleagues see laboratory skills as necessary and sufficient for our students, and view bioinformatics as an elective that just fills the schedule/adds needed units to graduation.
Students in the life sciences need coursework in computer science so that they understand that bioinformatics is not simply using existing software, but includes the ability to write code.
An evolution course is not required as part of our core curriculum. Two year programs are difficult to add additional courses to.
Some of the basic bioinformatics tools need to be integrated into other life sciences courses
